coredata.dc:title: Amorphous modified silyl-terminated 3D polymer electrolyte for high-performance lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Lin, Zhiyuan
Guo, Xianwei
Yu, Haijun
coredata.dc:description: Polymer electrolyte has been considered to eliminate the safety issue that caused by the lithium dendrite growth in the liquid electrolyte for the high-energy lithium metal battery. However, the practical applications of polymer electrolyte are still impeded by the low Li ionic conductivity, weak interfacial compatibility, low thermal stability and narrow electrochemical window. In this study, we have proposed a novel modified silyl-terminated polyether based polymer electrolyte by a cross-linking fabrication method. With a three-dimensional network structure, the amorphous polymer electrolyte has high ionic conductivity (~ 0.36mScm−1) at room temperature, much higher thermal stability (Tm = 379°C), high lithium ion transference number (~ 0.65), stable electrochemical window up to 5.0V (vs. Li+/Li) and an excellent compatibility to the electrode. With LiFePO4 cathode and this polymer electrolyte, the lithium metal battery delivers the high specific capacity of ~ 130mAhg−1 at 1C rate over 300 cycles, and ~ 105mAhg−1 at 3C rate with a superb cycling stability over 600 cycles at room temperature. We believe that this polymer electrolyte is a promising candidate for the practical applications and brings a new way to develop the high performance electrolyte for the lithium metal battery.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Modified silyl-terminated polyether
Cross-linking
Polymer electrolyte
High ionic conductivity
Lithium metal battery

xocs:item-toc-entry.xocs:item-toc-section-title: SEM, XRD and thermal stability analyses of MSTP-PE

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: (a) The optical figures of the MSTP-PE before and after the polymerization, and the schematic illustration of the preparation process with the structure of cross-linked network of MSTP-PE. (b) The molecular structures of the MSTP monomer and the MSTP-PE with the polymerization process. The chemical bonds in the light red area are the cross-linking parts. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article).
(a) SEM images of the MSTP-PE in top-view and cross section. (b) Phonographs of flexible MSTP-PE. (c) XRD spectrum of PEO- and MSTP-PE. (d) TG and DSC curves of MSTP-PE.

(a) The temperature dependency comparison of ionic conductivity of PEO- and MSTP-PE. (b) The chronoamperometry profile of a symmetric Li/MSTP-PE/Li battery under a polarization potential of 10mV, and the EIS before and after the polarization (insert). (c) EIS of a Li/MSTP-PE/Li symmetric battery for different aging time at room temperature. (d) Linear sweep voltammetry profile of the MSTP-PE at a scan rate of 1mVs−1, using a stainless steel as the working electrode, Li metal as the counter and reference electrode. The insert is the enlarged part for the current density within stable electrochemical window. (e) The potential profiles of repeated Li plating/striping using MSTP-PE with current density of 0.05mAcm−2 and 0.1mAcm−2 over 800h at 25°C. The inserts are the selected potential profiles with different current density.

(a) The comparisons of initial charge and discharge curves of LiFePO4 cathode with MSTP-PE and liquid electrolyte at 0.1C at room temperature. The inset is the corresponding CV for both batteries. (b) The stability of CV curves of LiFePO4/MSTP-PE/Li battery for 30 cycles. (c) Rate performances of LiFePO4/MSTP-PE/Li battery at room temperature. Cycling performance of LiFePO4/MSTP-PE/Li battery at (d) 1C and (e) 3C. The insets are the selected charge-discharge curves for both batteries with different cycles.
Optical photographs for the soft package LiFePO4/MSTP-PE/Li battery that (a), Potential monitoring, and powers a red LED: (b) cutting into several parts, (c) bending, and (d) wrinkled.

head.ce:title: Amorphous modified silyl-terminated 3D polymer electrolyte for high-performance lithium metal battery

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: College of Materials Sciences and Engineering, Beijing University of Technology, Beijing 100124, PR China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: College of Materials Sciences and Engineering, Beijing University of Technology

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: These authors contributed equally to this work.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Polymer electrolyte has been considered to eliminate the safety issue that caused by the lithium dendrite growth in the liquid electrolyte for the high-energy lithium metal battery. However, the practical applications of polymer electrolyte are still impeded by the low Li ionic conductivity, weak interfacial compatibility, low thermal stability and narrow electrochemical window. In this study, we have proposed a novel modified silyl-terminated polyether based polymer electrolyte by a cross-linking fabrication method. With a three-dimensional network structure, the amorphous polymer electrolyte has high ionic conductivity (~ 0.36mScm−1) at room temperature, much higher thermal stability (Tm = 379°C), high lithium ion transference number (~ 0.65), stable electrochemical window up to 5.0V (vs. Li+/Li) and an excellent compatibility to the electrode. With LiFePO4 cathode and this polymer electrolyte, the lithium metal battery delivers the high specific capacity of ~ 130mAhg−1 at 1C rate over 300 cycles, and ~ 105mAhg−1 at 3C rate with a superb cycling stability over 600 cycles at room temperature. We believe that this polymer electrolyte is a promising candidate for the practical applications and brings a new way to develop the high performance electrolyte for the lithium metal battery.

Amorphous polymer electrolyte using a novel modified silyl-terminated polyether possess high ionic conductivity (~ 0.36mScm−1) at room temperature, much higher thermal stability (Tm = 379°C), high lithium ion transference number (~ 0.65), stable electrochemical window up to 5.0V (vs. Li+/Li) and an excellent compatibility to the electrode. The lithium metal battery with developed polymer electrolyte present excellent electrochemical performance, showing strong potential for practical applications.
fx1

ce:section.ce:para: With the high theoretical specific capacity of metallic Li anode (3860mAhg−1), the rechargeable Li-metal batteries (LMBs) have reignited the researchers’ passions in recent years to meet the demands of high energy density and long lifetime of electric devices [1–10]. Nevertheless, there are still many obstacles for the further development of LMBs using liquid electrolyte, especially the safety issue that caused by the Li dendrite growth [7–14]. In order to improve the security and cycling stability of LMBs, the polymer electrolyte (PE) and inorganic solid electrolyte (ISE) have been developed to avoid the leakage and flammability of the liquid electrolyte [15–41]. Different from the ISE with the high sensitivity to moisture/oxygen and the rigid interfacial contacts with the electrodes, the PE has good flexibility and strong adhesion to the electrodes, and been considered as the promising candidate for the high performances LMBs [21–28]. Among the various PE, the poly (ethylene oxide) (PEO) as the earliest system, has been explored extensively because of several advantages [42–51]. However, with the high crystallinity of PEO, the lithium ions (Li+) migration has been restrained seriously, which causes the low ionic conductivity at room temperature [44–46]. Furthermore, PEO-PE is still suffered from narrow electrochemical window and weak interfacial compatibility to the electrodes, which extremely hinder their further applications in LMBs. Even worse, there were almost involving a lot of volatile organic solvent that may make a chemical waste and cause environmental problems for fabricating the PEO-PE when the solid powders as the reactive precursor [43–49]. Although plenty of modifications have been exploited for reducing or eliminating the crystallinity of PEO chains, it still cannot meet the requirements of high flexibility, high thermal stability, high ionic conductivity, and wide electrochemical window for the LMBs.

It has been reported that the polysiloxane (PSI)-PE has high ionic conductivity, low glass transition temperature (T g) and high flexibility because of the amorphous structure caused by the -[Si-O-] segments, which offer sufficient Li+ diffusion pathway [52–54]. However, most of the PSI-PE are liquids/gels at room temperature, which are not easy to be operated for the battery assembling. Inspired by the PEO- and PSI-PE, herein, we demonstrated a novel modified silyl-terminated polyether (MSTP)-PE with cross-linked network, which has been prepared via the facile polymerization from the MSTP monomer with lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) as the Li salt and the tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME) as the plasticizing agent. Unlike solid material as the precursor, the MSTP monomer is liquid that no need to be dissolved in the organic solvent. Moreover, the backbone of monomer has the silyl with [-Si-O-] on both terminals. Accordingly, the MSTP-PE can be obtained by the polymerization of terminal silyl without any change of the backbone chains, and has [-Si-O-] as the cross-linking parts that similar to the PSI, which facilitates the fast Li+ migrations [53]. Therefore, the amorphous structure of the MSTP-PE (arises from the polymerization of silyl) and the additive of the plasticizing agent have improved its ionic conductivity and the interfacial compatibility (the flexibility of the PE) to the electrodes, which are beneficial for improving the electrochemical performances of LMBs. Furthermore, there was no chemical release of organic solvent, UV-photo polymerization or hot pressing during the fabrication process, which can be defined as “Green Synthesis” for the PE. As a result, this amorphous MSTP-PE has a high ionic conductivity (~ 0.36mScm−1) at room temperature, much higher thermal stability (T m = 379°C), high lithium ion transference number (~ 0.65), stable electrochemical window up to 5.0V (vs. Li+/Li) and a good adhesion to the electrode. In addition, the polymer LMB with a LiFePO4 cathode can deliver the high specific capacity of ~ 130mAhg−1 at 1C rate over 300 cycles, and a specific capacity of ~ 105mAhg−1 at 3C rate with excellent cycling stability over 600 cycles at room temperature. Therefore, the MSTP-PE reported in this study is a promising candidate for the practical applications in high performances polymer LMBs.

The modified silyl-terminated polyether (MSTP) monomer used in this work was purchased from Aldrich. The lithium bis(trifluoromethane sulfonyl imide) (LiTFSI, 99%) and the tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether (TEGDME, 99%) were supplied by Macklin Company. The di-n-butyltin bis(2,4-pentanedionate) as the catalyst was obtained from Aldrich.

MSTP-PE was fabricated by a solution-casting method. Typically, MSTP (1.5g), LiTFSI (1g) and TEGDME (2mL) were added into the glass bottle in sequence under intense stirring to form a homogeneous solution. Subsequently, the catalyst (5 μL) was added into the solution and stirred for 30min. Then the homogeneous solution was poured into the Whatman® filter (100% borosilicate glass fiber) on the PTFE plate followed by the polymerization in a vacuum oven at 60°C for 3h and then 80°C for 3h. Pristine PEO polymer electrolyte (PEO-PE) was fabricated via similar method without the filter supporting matrix.

The morphology of the sample was characterized by a field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi S-4800). The thickness of the PE was also tested by the SEM. DSC (Perkin Elmer) was carried out to measure the thermal property of the polymer electrolyte from 25 to 800°C at a heating rate of 10°Cmin −1 under nitrogen atmosphere. XRD (Bruker D8 Advance) were recorded in the range of 10–60°.

Ionic conductivity of the solid polymer electrolytes was tested by EIS using an VersaSTAT 3 system at varied temperatures ranging from 0 to 80°C. The polymer electrolyte membranes were sandwiched between two stainless-steel (SS) plate electrodes and the spectra were recorded in the frequency range of 0.1–105 Hz with an AC amplitude of 10mV. The bulk resistance (R b) of membrane was determined from the impedance spectrum. The ionic conductivity (σ) was calculated from Eq. (1)
(1)

where R b is the bulk resistance and L and S are the thickness and area of the polymer electrolyte, respectively. The electrochemical stability window was investigated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) performed on a working electrode of stainless steel, Li metal as the counter and reference electrode of MSTP electrolyte at a scan rate of 1.0mVs−1 between 0 and 6.0V. The lithium-ion transference number (tLi +) was calculated by the chronoamperometry test on the Li/MSTP-PE/Li battery with an applied voltage of 0.01V and was determined by following equation:

where I0 and Iss are the initial and steady-state currents, and R0 and Rss are the first and last resistances, respectively. The tests were completed by EIS measurements taken before and after the polarization scans over a frequency range of 0.1–105 Hz with a 10mV amplitude in the room temperature.
The mechanical property of the MSTP-PE was investigated by a tensile machine (UTM4304) at a stretching speed of 10cmmin−1 for the sample with the width of about 1cm and length of 8cm.

The LiFePO4 or LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 (NCA) cathode was composed of 80wt% LiFePO4 /NCA, 10wt% PVDF, and 10wt% carbon black. Areal density of obtained LiFePO4 (NCA) cathode was 1.2–3.0mgcm−2. The LiFePO4/MSTP-PE/Li battery was charged and discharged between 2.5 and 4.0V at varied current densities. The C rates in all of the electrochemical measurements are defined based on 1C = 170mAg−1. The battery was assembled in an argon-filled glove box, with oxygen content less than 5ppm and H2O content less than 1ppm. The galvanostatic charge/discharge tests of coin-type battery (CR2032) were conducted on LAND testing system (Wuhan LAND electronics Co., Ltd.) at 25°C. The battery with the LiFePO4 cathode using 1M LiPF6-EC/DMC liquid electrolyte was also assembled and tested in the same condition.

MSTP-PE was fabricated by a facile cross-linked casting method. As shown in Fig. 1 a, for the typical fabrication process, the liquid MSTP monomer, Li salt and a certain amount of plasticizing agent were added into a glass bottle simultaneously, followed by the intense stirring to form a homogeneous solution. Subsequently, the solution was poured into the filter paper on the PTFE plate and then dried for polymerization in a vacuum oven [26]. Fig. 1 a also shows the schematic diagram of the precursor and the corresponding cross-linked network structure of MSTP-PE after fully polymerization. For the detail, the MSTP monomer has the polyether backbone with the silyl on both terminals (Fig. 1 b). After polymerization of terminal silyl, the MSTP-PE can be obtained without any change of the backbone chain, in which the [-Si-O-] as the cross-linking part (the red area in Fig. 1 a and b). For comparison, the pristine PEO-PE was also prepared via similar method without any modification.

ce:section.ce:section-title: SEM, XRD and thermal stability analyses of MSTP-PE
ce:section.ce:para: The surface and cross-section of as-prepared MSTP-PE have been revealed by the scanning electron microscopy (SEM). From Fig. 2 a, it can be found that the surface of PE is smooth and homogenous, which is beneficial for the strong adhesion to the electrodes with superb interfacial contact. The cross-section SEM image of MSTP-PE (the inset of Fig. 2 a) demonstrates that the pores of the fibrous matrix in filter paper were fully filled by the PE, and the thickness of MSTP-PE is ~ 210µm (Fig. S1). With the favorable mechanical property, the continuous and homogeneous structure of the MSTP-PE are essential to prevent the possible short circuits of the LMBs (Fig. S2). Furthermore, the MSTP-PE is variable in size and has a good flexibility, which is easy to be handled for electrochemical test (Fig. 2 b). Therefore, the continuous and homogenous MSTP-PE has a good interfacial compatibility for the assembling with electrodes, which are favorable for alleviating the possible inner short-circuit of the batteries and improving the safety and reliability of LMBs.

The structure of the MSTP-PE has been detected by X-ray diffraction (XRD) and has been shown in Fig. 2 c. Different from the crystallinity of PEO-PE with several intense peaks, there is only a broad peak of the MSTP-PE, indicating the amorphous structure of PE, which is beneficial for enhancing the Li+ conductivity by increasing the mobility of the polymer chains as well as lowering the activation energy for ionic transport [48]. Accordingly, the ductility of amorphous PE could be enhanced for improving the interfacial contact with the electrodes, which is unachievable for the crystalline PE with rigid property. It's well known that the crystalline structure of PEO-PE could be destroyed due to the melting of PEO crystallites when the temperature was over 50°C, and may cause the seriously internal short-circuit and explosion owing to poor integrity for the operating of LMBs [43–49]. However, from the thermal gravimetric (TG) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) curves, the melting point (T m) of the MSTP-PE is approximately 379°C, which is much higher than that of PEO-PE (Fig. 2 c). More importantly, there is no obvious variation of the TG curve below 150°C, indicating the stable phase composition below this high temperature. Therefore, the superior thermal stability of MSTP-PE could significantly improve the safety issue by eliminating the possible short circuit of LMBs at high temperature.

The ionic conductivity of PE has a critical role for improving the performances of LMBs. From the electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of a SS/MSTP-PE/SS symmetrical battery at different temperature in Fig. S3a, the bulk resistance (R b, the resistance of PE) decreases gradually with the increase of temperature, indicating the increase of ionic conductivity of MSTP-PE. Fig. 3 a reveals the temperature dependency and comparison of the ionic conductivity of MSTP-PE and PEO-PE at various temperature ranging from 0°C to 80°C. Obviously, the ionic conductivity of MSTP-PE was 3.6 × 10−4 Scm−1 at 25°C, which is much higher than that of PEO-PE (2.1 × 10−6 Scm−1). Furthermore, the ionic conductivity of MSTP-PE, which is always much higher than that of PEO-PE at the testing temperature range, has a significant difference of the tendency, and more importantly, is approximately linear relationship between logσ and 1000/T, indicating no obvious structure change occurs in the MSTP-PE within this temperature range. It has been confirmed that the PEO-PE with high crystallization has greatly restrained the lithium migration, resulting in the low Li-ionic conductivity at room temperature. However, the ionic conductivity of MSTP-PE at the same condition was much higher than that of PEO-PE, which should be attributed to the following two reasons. Firstly, the complex interactions between Li+ and the units comprising oxygen in the homogenous MSTP-PE may in favor for the fast Li ions migrations via the cross-linking chains of backbones. Secondly, the amorphous structure prominently enhances the ionic mobility of the polymer chains and reduce the activation energy for Li+ transport. Surprisingly, the MSTP-PE has a high ionic conductivity of 3.53 × 10−3 Scm−1 at 80°C with outstanding thermal stability, which can avoid the internal short circuit of the batteries. Furthermore, the R b has a slight decrease from 65Ω at initial state to 41Ω after 30 days, which should be generated by the internal relaxation of PE during the storage time (Fig. S3b). Therefore, with the enhanced ionic conductivity, high thermal stability and improved flexibility at the elevated temperature, the safety issue as well as the electrochemical performances of MSTP-PE based LMBs can be enhanced significantly.

The lithium ion transference number (tLi +) is also one of the indispensable parameters to evaluate the property of PE. Generally, the tLi + is about 0.2–0.5 for the common liquid electrolyte (0.38 for 1M LiPF6-EC/EMC/DMC) and 0.05–0.3 for the generally obtained PEO-PE [43–49,55,56]. More seriously, the polarization and unavoidable side reactions of the electrodes may be increased by the high concentration of mobile anions in the electrolyte [57]. By contrast, the tLi + of the MSTP-PE is approximately 0.65 (Fig. 3 b), which is much higher than that of liquid electrolyte and PEO-PE. As an excellent Li+-dominant conductor, the movement of anions in the MSTP-PE can be restrained greatly, which is beneficial for reducing the polarization and improving the performances of LMBs. Generally, the interfacial compatibility between the PE and the Li metal anode is important for practical applications. From the EIS of a Li/MSTP-PE/Li symmetrical cell before and after polarization in the inset in Fig. 3 b, there is no obvious change of R b (the resistance of PE) and interfacial resistance (R i), indicating the stable ionic conductivity of PE and interfacial contact between the PE and the Li electrodes. Furthermore, the interfacial stability has also been verified by EIS after long aging time (Fig. 3 c). It can be seen that the R b decreases slightly from ~ 103Ω at initial state to ~ 78Ω after interior stabilization for 10 days, similar to that of the tendency in the SS/MSTP-PE/SS symmetric battery (Fig. S3b). After that, there was no obvious change of R b with aging time from 10 to 30 days, indicating that the conductivity of MSTP-PE keeps stable over long time. Moreover, the R i has a same tendency for the following 20 days aging after stabilization, demonstrating a stable interfacial resistance layer on the surface of Li electrodes. Therefore, the MSTP-PE has an outstanding stability with aging time and an excellent interfacial compatibility toward Li metal electrode, which can improve the electrochemical performances of polymer LMBs. The electrochemical window of PE is also crucial for potential practical application. By a linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) scan of the PE that sandwiched between stainless steel and Li metal plates (Fig. 3 d), the MSTP-PE is stable up to 5.0V vs. Li+/Li from the anodic scan part, which is considered as a promising candidate for the high-voltage polymer LMBs4. Moreover, the cathodic profile has revealed the reversible and stable lithium plating and stripping processes, which will be discussed in the following part.

The dynamically interfacial stability between the PE and Li metal anode has been investigated by the polarization test of the symmetric battery for a long time (Fig. 3 e). It can be seen that the over-potential is about 0.1 and 0.2mV for the plating and stripping of lithium metal in the Li/MSTP-PE/Li symmetric battery at the current density of 0.05 and 0.1mAcm−2, respectively. It's delighted to find that the battery maintains an extremely low voltage polarization without short circuiting after cycled for over 800h, demonstrating the highly stable cycling reversibility and stability for lithium plating/stripping in this MSTP-PE based battery. The fluctuation of potential was caused by the environmental temperature change. Surprisingly, the potentials decrease apparently with the increase of cycling time, which is quite different from the liquid electrolyte with the potential increases. Similar potential decrease has also been observed in the other PE, and the reason was attributed to the improved interface between the electrolyte membrane and lithium metal during the repeated Li electrodeposition [40]. Therefore, the low interfacial resistance with an excellent compatibility to the electrodes as well as the high ionic conductivity of MSTP-PE can greatly enhance the cycling stability and rate capability of the polymer LMBs.

As the LiFePO4 has shown to be stable as cathode for exploring the feasibility of PE, the LiFePO4/MSTP-PE/Li battery is assembled to evaluate the cycling stabilities and rate performances of MSTP-PE based LMBs. Fig. 4 a shows the initial charge-discharge curve with stable potential plateaus of LiFePO4/MSTP-PE/Li battery at the current density of 0.1C (1C = 170mAhg−1) at room temperature, which can be confirmed by the cyclic voltammogram (CV) of the LiFePO4 cathode (Inset in Fig. 4 a). Although the over-potential between the discharge-charge potentials is a little higher than that of the battery using 1M LiPF6-EC/DMC liquid electrolyte, the MSTP-PE based battery still delivers a high initial discharge capacity of ~ 152mAhg−1 with the coulombic efficiency approaches 98%, which is comparable to that of the liquid electrolyte based battery. Meanwhile, the specific capacity still keeps as high as ~ 147mAhg−1 with a capacity retention ratio of ~ 97% after 30 cycles, indicating a high cycling stability for the polymer LMBs (Fig. S4a), which has been further verified by the CV after 30 cycles without obvious shift of the peak position (Fig. 4 b). It is impressive to see that even at the low temperature of 5°C and high temperature of 60°C, the battery can deliver the high capacity of ~ 126 and ~ 154mAhg−1, respectively, indicating the excellent stability of MSTP-PE for the LMBs at variable temperature (Fig. S4b).

Fig. 4 c exhibits the rate performance of the LiFePO4/MSTP-PE/Li battery with the current densities increase from 0.5C to 3C. The charge plateau rises while the discharge plateau declines with the increasing rate, which should be originated from the polarization effect, and causes the capacity decreases continuously with the increase of current densities (Insert in Fig. 4 c). The battery shows a high specific capacity of ~ 152mAhg−1 at a low current density of 0.5C, and ~ 120mAhg−1 at a current density of 2C. Even at a high current density of 3C, the specific capacity is still remains to be ~ 100mAhg−1. Moreover, the cycling stability of the LiFePO4/MSTP-PE/Li battery is obtained in the same condition at the rate of 1C (Fig. 4 d). Surprisingly, the reversible capacity is ~ 115mAhg−1 from the initial cycle and increases to ~ 126mAhg−1 over 300 cycles with the high coulombic efficiency of 99%, which should be attributed to the improved interfacial compatibility between the MSTP-PE and the electrodes. Also there is no obvious variation of the over-potentials between the charge and discharge potentials after hundreds of cycles, which supports the excellent stability of the PE (Insert in Fig. 4 d). More importantly, with the high current density of 3C, the battery can deliver the high specific capacity of ~ 100mAhg−1 over 600 cycles with 99.7% of the efficiency (Fig. 4 e). The fluctuation of specific capacity was caused by the environmental temperature variation. Furthermore, the EIS of the LiFePO4/MSTP-PE/Li battery has been explored to evaluate the interfacial behavior after hundreds of cycles at 0.5C (Fig. S5). As it shown, the interfacial resistance keeps decreasing with the increasing cycles, which should be caused by the improved interface between the PE and the electrodes during charging and discharging, consisting with the increased specific capacity for long cycling (Fig. 4 d) and the decrease of the over-potentials in the symmetric Li/MSTP-PE/Li battery (Fig. 3 e). Therefore, the high reversible capacity at variable temperature, outstanding rate performance and excellent cycling stability of the LiFePO4/MSTP-PE/Li battery apparently benefit from the high ionic conductivity, high thermal stability and excellent interfacial compatibility between PE and electrodes. In addition, the MSTP-PE can be applied for other cathodes, such as LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 with a pretty good electrochemical performance (Fig. S6).

In order to explore the potential application of MSTP-PE for practical devices, the soft-package lithium battery comprising LiFePO4 cathode and lithium metal anode has been developed and was shown in Fig. 5. It is demonstrated that the potential of the LiFePO4/MSTP-PE/Li soft-package battery is similar to that of the coin battery (Fig. 5 a). It is worth noting that the soft-package battery can still be able to light up a commercial red light-emitting diode (LED) lamp after it is cut into several parts consecutively, indicating no short-circuit of the battery at this harsh condition (Fig. 5 b). Surprisingly, the battery lights up the same red LED lamp successfully when the battery was bended (Fig. 5 c), and severely wrinkled (Fig. 5 d) without any electrical failure during the process, which can be as the powerful evidence to prove the excellent deformability and reliability of our MSTP-PE for the polymer LMBs. Therefore, the application of our MSTP-PE can be expanded to other energy-storage devices, including the wearable devices.

In conclusion, we proposed a novel MSTP-PE that fabricated by the cross-linking of silyl in the monomer for the polymer LMBs. Combing the fast Li+ migrations in the backbones and the cross-liked network by polymerization of silyl that the main component in polysiloxane, it has been demonstrated that the amorphous and homogenous MSTP-PE has the high Li ion conductivity, excellent flexibility, high thermal stability and the wide electrochemical window. By using this new PE, the LiFePO4/MSTP-PE/Li battery exhibits highly reversible specific capacities at variable temperature, excellent cycling stability and outstanding rate performances at room temperature. More impressively, such polymer soft-package battery delivers excellent safety and flexibility even in some harsh conditions. Therefore, the MSTP-PE is one of the most promising candidates to meet the demands of LMBs with high energy density, superb safety issue and excellent reliability. These results also demonstrate a new way to develop stable PE for the high-performance metal batteries.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: This work was supported financially by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grants 51622202, U1507107 and 21503009), Beijing Natural Science Foundation (B) (KZ201610005003), Guangdong Science and Technology Project (2016B010114001) and the Funding Projects for “Thousand Youth Talents Plan”.

ce:section.ce:label: Appendix A
ce:section.ce:para: Supplementary data associated with this article can be found in the online version at doi:10.1016/j.nanoen.2017.10.021.
